translation.content_en: https://www.macrumors.com/2026/01/09/senators-apple-google-remove-grok/ X was embroiled in controversy last week following reports that Grok's AI image generation feature was used to create images depicting women and children in bikinis or underwear. In response, X appears to have restricted Grok's image generation capabilities for non-paying users' posts; however, according to The Verge, the feature remains available to paid subscribers through the dedicated Grok tab on the X platform and the standalone Grok app. Senators argue that these "potentially harmful and illegal depictions" violate the app store terms of both Apple and Google, asserting that the two companies should remove the app until the policy violations are addressed. Apple's terms of service prohibit apps from containing "offensive" or "creepy" content, which by any definition includes non-consensual sexual imagery of children and women. Furthermore, Apple's terms explicitly forbid apps from including "overtly sexual or pornographic material," specifically material intended to "stimulate erotic rather than aesthetic or emotional feelings." The senators stated that condoning X's malicious behavior would make a mockery of the companies' content moderation policies. They warned that failing to take action would undermine their claimsâ€”both publicly and in courtâ€”that their app stores provide a safer user experience than direct side-loading. These principles have served as a core justification for opposing legislative reforms aimed at increasing app store competition and defending against allegations that their app stores abuse market dominance through payment systems. The senators have requested a written response to their letter by January 23. In response, Musk stated, "The real reason they are freaking out is because they hate free speech." (...)

structured.content_en:
U.S. Senators have demanded that Apple and Google remove X from their app stores due to harmful AI images generated by Grok. This move puts App Store safety policies to the test.

## Why It Matters
This demand directly addresses the moderation responsibilities of platforms. Big Tech companies must adhere to the regulations they have established. If they fail to take action, the security logic of the App Store collapses, which could also influence future antitrust litigation.

## Background
Grok sparked controversy by generating sexually explicit images of children. X continues to allow this feature for its paid users. Apple's terms of service prohibit pornography and offensive content, but Elon Musk argues that these demands constitute a suppression of free speech.

## Common Misconceptions
It is a common misconception that AI-generated content is not subject to App Store regulations. Apple evaluates the harmfulness of the output regardless of how it was created.

## FAQ
**Q: Why is the removal of the app being demanded now?**
A: Sexually explicit images of children and women have violated platform policies.

**Q: What is X's official stance?**
A: Musk criticized the senators, claiming they despise freedom of speech.

**Q: What is the upcoming schedule?**
A: The senators have requested written responses from both companies by January 23.

## Next Steps
Monitor the official responses from Apple and Google. Watch for whether Grok strengthens its filtering for image generation.
